title: Go for JavaScript developers
description: A practical Go course that maps JavaScript mental models to idiomatic Go.

challenges.title: Hello, Go
challenges.summary: Run your first Go program and print a message.
challenges.prompt: Create a Go program that prints "Hello, Go!" and your name.
acceptance_criteria: Output includes "Hello, Go!" and a name
hints: Every Go program starts in package main
Use fmt.Println to print a line
extended_hints: In Go, functions must be inside a package; the entry point is main() in package main.
Unlike JavaScript, you must import fmt before using fmt.Println.

challenges.title: Variables and Types
challenges.summary: Declare variables with explicit and inferred types.
challenges.prompt: Declare a string and an integer, then print both in a single line.
acceptance_criteria: Uses at least one explicit type
Uses at least one inferred type
hints: Use var name type = value for explicit types
extended_hints: Go is statically typed, so every variable has a fixed type unlike JavaScript.
The := syntax is similar to let in JS but only works inside functions.

challenges.title: Functions and Returns
challenges.summary: Create a function that returns a value.
challenges.prompt: Write a function add(a, b int) int that returns the sum, then print the result.
hints: Put the return type after the parameters
extended_hints: Go doesnâ€™t have implicit returns like JS arrow functions; use return explicitly.
Parameter types can share a single type if they are the same: a, b int.

challenges.title: Conditionals
challenges.prompt: Write a function that returns "large" if a number is >= 10, otherwise "small".
acceptance_criteria: Returns correct string for both cases
extended_hints: Go does not allow parentheses around the if condition like JavaScript.
You can short-declare variables inside if: if x := value; x > 10 {}

challenges.title: Loops
challenges.summary: Use for loops for counting and iteration.
challenges.prompt: Print the numbers 1 through 5 using a for loop.
hints: Go only has for for looping
extended_hints: There is no while keyword in Go; use for with a condition instead.
The ++ operator is a statement, not an expression as in JS.

challenges.title: Slices
challenges.summary: Work with dynamic arrays in Go.
challenges.prompt: Create a slice of three favorite tools and append a fourth one, then print them.
extended_hints: Slices are like JS arrays but with a fixed element type.
append returns a new slice; assign it back to the variable.

challenges.title: Maps
challenges.prompt: Create a map of framework names to popularity scores and print one score.
extended_hints: Maps are like JS objects but with explicit key/value types.
Reading a missing key returns the zero value and a boolean ok flag.

challenges.title: Structs
challenges.prompt: Define a struct for a Course with title and level fields, then create and print one.
hints: Struct fields are declared inside type ... struct
extended_hints: Structs are closer to JS objects with fixed fields and types.
You can create struct values with field names: Course{Title: "..."}.

challenges.title: Methods
challenges.summary: Attach behavior to structs with methods.
challenges.prompt: Add a method on Course that returns a display label, then call it.
acceptance_criteria: Defines a method with a receiver
hints: Methods look like functions with a receiver
Receiver goes before the function name
extended_hints: Receiver methods are similar to class methods, but Go has no classes.
Use value receivers unless you need to mutate the struct.

challenges.title: Error Handling
challenges.summary: Return errors instead of throwing exceptions.
challenges.prompt: Write a function that divides two numbers and returns an error when dividing by zero.
acceptance_criteria: Returns a value and an error
Returns an error on division by zero
hints: Use fmt.Errorf to create an error
extended_hints: Go uses explicit error returns instead of try/catch.
The zero value for float64 is 0.0, which is useful for error cases.

challenges.title: Pointers
challenges.prompt: Write a function that increments an int using a pointer, then demonstrate it.
extended_hints: Pointers in Go are similar to JS objects passed by reference, but explicit.
Only use pointers when you need to mutate or avoid copying.

challenges.title: Interfaces
challenges.prompt: Create a Speaker interface with Speak() string and implement it for two structs.
hints: A struct implements an interface by having the methods
extended_hints: Go interfaces are like structural typing in TypeScript.
You do not need an explicit implements keyword.

challenges.title: Concurrency with Goroutines
challenges.prompt: Launch two goroutines that print different messages and wait for both to finish.
acceptance_criteria: Ensures main waits for both goroutines
extended_hints: Goroutines are lightweight threads managed by the Go runtime.
WaitGroup is the simplest way to wait for multiple goroutines.

challenges.title: Channels
challenges.prompt: Create a goroutine that sends a message over a channel and print it in main.
acceptance_criteria: Sends a value from a goroutine
extended_hints: Channels are typed pipes; they help avoid shared memory.
Receiving blocks until a value is available.

challenges.title: Build a CLI Task List
challenges.summary: Combine structs, slices, and file I/O for a small project.
challenges.prompt: Create a CLI that stores tasks in a slice and writes them to a file as plain text.
extended_hints: os.WriteFile is like fs.writeFileSync but returns an error.
strings.Builder is efficient for concatenating many strings.
